title: 107_hr542
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Review Panel Technical Amendments Act of 1999". The Congress recognizes the importance of a vibrant small business sector for job creation in the economy. Small businesses face a disproportionate amount of regulatory burdens, and federal agencies need to consider their impact on small businesses early in the rulemaking process. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process, established in 1996, allows small businesses to participate in the development of regulations. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process, established in 1996, allows small businesses to participate in rules developed by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. The purposes of this Act are to provide a forum for small businesses in the federal regulatory process and to clarify and strengthen the Review Panel process. The Act aims to enhance small businesses' participation in federal regulations by providing a forum and improving the Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process. It also seeks to increase the number of federal agencies required to convene these panels. The Act aims to enhance small businesses' participation in federal regulations by improving the Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process and increasing the number of federal agencies required to convene these panels. SEC. 3 ensures full analysis of potential impacts on small entities of rules proposed by certain agencies. Section 609(b) of title 5, United States Code is amended to require covered agencies to notify the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This aims to provide information on the potential impacts of proposed rules on small entities. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must be notified before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This includes providing information on the potential impacts of proposed rules on small entities and identifying affected small entity representatives for advice and recommendations. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must be notified before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This involves transmitting information to identified small entity representatives for advice on potential impacts of the draft proposed rule. After 30 days, a review panel of full-time Federal employees will be convened to assess the proposed rule. The covered agency will convene a review panel consisting of full-time Federal employees responsible for the proposed rule, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, and the Chief Counsel. The panel will review materials prepared for the proposed rule and gather advice from small entity representatives. The covered agency will convene a review panel to collect advice and recommendations from small entity representatives on specific issues related to the proposed rule. Small entity representatives may also make oral presentations to the panel upon request within 60 days of the panel's formation. The review panel formed by the covered agency will report to the agency head within 60 days, including comments from small entity representatives and findings on specific issues outlined in the regulations. The agency head is required to publish the panel's report in the Federal Register promptly. The covered agency must publish the review panel's report in the Federal Register within 120 days of receiving it or as part of the proposed rulemaking publication. The agency may need to make modifications based on the report's findings. The covered agency must modify the draft proposed rule, initial regulatory flexibility analysis, or decision as needed. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 609(d) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define 'covered agency' as the Environmental Protection Agency, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the Department of Labor, and the Internal Revenue Service of the Department of the Treasury, and 'small entity representative' as a small entity or an individual/organization representing a small entity. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will take effect after a 90-day period from its enactment.
